facts.fact: The holes in the studs of LEGO minifigure heads are a safety feature to prevent suffocation if a child swallows one.
LEGO has an official designation for master builders called 'LEGO Certified Professionals.' There are only about 40 in the entire world.
The mold for the classic 2x4 LEGO brick is so precise that there is a tolerance of less than two-thousandths of a millimeter (0.002 mm).
The first licensed LEGO theme was a wooden toy line based on the cartoon character 'Woody Woodpecker' in the 1950s, long before Star Wars.
The iconic LEGO yellow for minifigures was chosen to best represent all races and ethnicities in a neutral, non-specific way.
LEGO almost went bankrupt in the early 2000s, but was saved by the success of the Bionicle and LEGO Star Wars lines.
The LEGO Group has a team of 'Brick Masters' whose job is to test the 'playability' of new sets.
LEGO bricks are made from a specific plastic called Acrylonitrile Butadiene Styrene (ABS), which gives them their signature clutch power and gloss.
The LEGO company owns the largest private collection of an artist's work: the art of Carl Barks, who drew the Donald Duck comics.
There are over 900 million different ways to combine just six eight-stud LEGO bricks of the same color.
The tiny 'LEGO' logo is molded onto the top of every stud, a mark of authenticity.
The LEGO Ideas platform allows fans to submit their own creations; if a project gets 10,000 votes, LEGO will consider making it an official set.
The first LEGO minifigure with a double-sided head was Professor Quirrell from the Harry Potter theme, showing Voldemort on the back.
In 1997, a container ship lost nearly 5 million LEGO pieces off the coast of Cornwall, UK. Beachcombers still find them washed ashore today.
The LEGO color palette has a special color called 'Modulex White' which is slightly different from standard white, used for their architectural line in the 1960s.
The LEGO Duplo brick, which is twice the size of a standard brick, is still perfectly compatible with the smaller bricks.
The LEGO Group briefly made a line of educational software in the 1990s, including the popular game 'LEGO Island'.

The name of the LEGO space theme's founder, Godtfred Kirk Christiansen, can be found on the side of the spaceship from the classic set #497/#928, Galaxy Explorer. His initials, 'GKC', are printed on the hull.
LEGO created a special, limited-edition brick made of solid 14-karat gold, which was given to employees with 25 years of service.
The LEGO Bionicle storyline was so complex it had its own dedicated story team and a mythology that spanned over a decade.
The LEGO company has an official policy against creating sets based on modern warfare or real-life military vehicles.
LEGO once created a line of scented bricks called 'Scala' aimed at young girls in the 1990s.
The tallest LEGO structure ever built was a 114-foot tower, requiring over 500,000 bricks.
There's a LEGO brick separator tool designed to help take apart stubborn pieces without damaging them or your teeth.
The LEGO Technic line, with its gears and pins, was originally called 'Expert Builder'.
In the LEGO House, a massive 'Tree of Creativity' is one of the largest LEGO models in the world, standing over 50 feet tall.
The LEGO Group's official motto is 'Det bedste er ikke for godt,' which means 'Only the best is good enough'.
The first LEGO minifigures from 1978 had no facial expressions other than a neutral smile.
LEGO minifigure hands are designed to be C-shaped to perfectly grip LEGO bars and accessories.
The LEGO company is still privately owned by the Kirk Kristiansen family who founded it.
There is a system of underground tunnels ('utilidors') beneath the Magic Kingdom in Florida so cast members can move around without being seen by guests.
The drawbridge on Sleeping Beauty's Castle at Disneyland is real and functional but has only been publicly lowered twice: on opening day in 1955 and for the Fantasyland redesign in 1983.
In 'Toy Story', the pattern on the carpet in Sid's house is the same as the iconic carpet from the Overlook Hotel in 'The Shining'.
Disneyland's exclusive Club 33 has a multi-year waiting list and an initiation fee reportedly over $25,000.
The 'Partners' statue of Walt and Mickey has a subtle imperfection: Walt Disney's tie has a non-traditional Windsor knot, which was how he always wore his.
The final film Walt Disney personally oversaw was 'The Jungle Book'.
The 'grim grinning ghosts' in the Haunted Mansion's ballroom scene are created using a 19th-century illusion technique called Pepper's Ghost.
The voice of Lilo from 'Lilo & Stitch' is Daveigh Chase, the same actress who played the terrifying Samara in 'The Ring'.
In 'The Emperor's New Groove', Yzma's original plan was to blot out the sun with a giant disc, a plot that was deemed too similar to a 'Simpsons' episode.
There is a 'Tower of Terror' themed hotel suite in the Tokyo DisneySea Hotel MiraCosta.
The animal sounds in the jungle of 'The Lion King' were partially recorded from the tigers and lions at the San Francisco Zoo.
The iconic Disney monorail system was the first daily operating monorail in the Western Hemisphere.
The face of the Mad Hatter in 'Alice in Wonderland' was modeled after his voice actor, Ed Wynn.
Disney's 'The Black Cauldron' was the company's first animated film to receive a PG rating.
The names of the four main characters in 'The Jungle Book'—Mowgli, Baloo, Bagheera, and Shere Khan—are the Hindi words for 'frog,' 'bear,' 'panther,' and 'tiger king' respectively.
In 'Beauty and the Beast', Belle is the only person in her village who wears blue, symbolizing her status as an outsider.
The sorcerer in 'Fantasia' is named 'Yen Sid,' which is 'Disney' spelled backward.
Walt Disney's personal apartment, which is still maintained, is located above the Fire Department on Main Street in Disneyland.
The movie 'Pocahontas' had its world premiere in New York's Central Park, with an audience of over 100,000 people.
The Disney company is the world's second-largest consumer of explosives, just after the U.S. Department of Defense, due to their nightly fireworks shows.
The design for the character WALL-E was inspired by a pair of binoculars.
The Beast in 'Beauty and the Beast' is a chimerical creature with the head of a buffalo, the mane of a lion, the tusks of a boar, and the body of a bear.
The original voice of Bambi, Donnie Dunagan, grew up to become a decorated Marine Corps drill instructor.
The 'hidden Mickey' phenomenon started as an inside joke among Disney Imagineers.
The Liberty Bell in Disneyland's Liberty Square is a real replica cast from the same mold as the original.
Disney's 'Moana' is the first Disney Princess film where the main character has no love interest.
The voice of Eeyore, Ralph Wright, was also a storyboard artist for many Disney classics and was known for his naturally gloomy demeanor.
The Disney family crest can be seen on the Cinderella Castle in Walt Disney World.
The film 'Tangled' was Disney's 50th animated feature film.
The 'fainting' goat in 'Frozen' is a real breed of goat known as the Myotonic goat, which stiffens and falls over when startled.
The bounty hunter Bossk's costume in 'The Empire Strikes Back' is a recycled spacesuit from a 'Doctor Who' episode.
Denis Lawson, who played the rebel pilot Wedge Antilles, is the maternal uncle of Ewan McGregor, who played Obi-Wan Kenobi.
The sound of the Droideka's blaster is a looped and pitched-up recording of a Tasmanian Devil.
Nien Nunb's dialogue is actually a mix of the Haya language from Tanzania and some Kikuyu, a language from Kenya.
In early drafts of 'A New Hope', R2-D2 could speak standard English and was reportedly quite foul-mouthed.
The Imperial March was not introduced until 'The Empire Strikes Back'; it does not appear in 'A New Hope'.
George Lucas financed 'The Empire Strikes Back' and 'Return of the Jedi' himself, allowing him to retain full creative control.
The iconic opening crawl was created by a practical effects company called 'Industrial Light & Magic' (ILM) by physically filming a large model of the text.
Luke Skywalker's original lightsaber prop was made from the handle of a 1930s Graflex camera flash.
The term 'Padawan' was created for the prequel trilogy and does not appear in the original films.
The sound of Chewbacca's crossbow-like weapon, the Bowcaster, is the sound of a slinky being hit.
The original trilogy was filmed with a specific, soft-focus lens to give it a more 'used future' and slightly grimy look.
The word 'Ewok' is never actually spoken aloud in 'Return of the Jedi'.
The species of Admiral Ackbar, the Mon Calamari, were first designed as generic aliens for the Cantina scene.
In 'The Phantom Menace', a delegation of E.T.'s species can be seen in the Galactic Senate.
The design of the Millennium Falcon's cockpit was inspired by the cockpit of a B-29 Superfortress bomber.
The sound of a lightsaber igniting is the sound of a film projector motor starting up combined with the hum of an old television.
Harrison Ford was not originally supposed to play Han Solo; he was just helping read lines with other actors during auditions.
The scene where Luke and Leia swing across the Death Star chasm was performed by the actors themselves, without stunt doubles.
The planet Coruscant was first named and developed in Timothy Zahn's 1991 novel 'Heir to the Empire' before appearing in the films.
The creature inside the trash compactor in 'A New Hope' was named the 'Dianoga.'
Jabba the Hutt was operated by a team of three puppeteers from inside the massive puppet.
The sound of the Tusken Raiders' cry is a manipulated recording of a donkey's bray.
George Lucas originally envisioned Han Solo as a large, green-skinned alien with gills.
An early concept for Yoda had him as a much larger, elf-like creature.
The sound of the speeder bikes in 'Return of the Jedi' is a mix of a P-51 Mustang and a P-38 Lightning fighter plane.
The 'Force ghost' effect was created by filming the actors through a special, semi-transparent material.
The rolling droid BB-8 was a practical effect, not CGI, and was operated live on set.
The blaster bolts in the original trilogy were drawn in by hand, frame by frame, in a process called rotoscoping.
The original Star Wars film had a budget of only $11 million.
The Galaxy's first-ever goal was scored by Cobi Jones on April 13, 1996.
The team's official supporters' group, the Angel City Brigade, sits in section 121 of the stadium.
In 2000, the Galaxy won the CONCACAF Champions' Cup, making them one of only two MLS teams to ever win the tournament.
The Galaxy's USL affiliate team is officially named LA Galaxy II, but is nicknamed 'Los Dos'.
The Galaxy's home stadium was the first soccer-specific stadium built in the United States by a Major League Soccer team.
The Galaxy once had a third jersey that was predominantly red, nicknamed the 'Salsa Picante' jersey.
The team's rivalry with the San Jose Earthquakes is called the 'California Clásico' and is one of the oldest rivalries in MLS.
The LA Galaxy's academy was the first of its kind in MLS and has produced numerous professional players.
The team's mascot, Cozmo, is said to be from the planet 'Planetaria'.
The LA Galaxy won the first-ever MLS Cup Supporters' Shield in 1998 for having the best regular season record.
The Galaxy's first head coach was Lothar Osiander, who also coached the U.S. Olympic soccer team.
The team's name, 'Galaxy,' was chosen to reflect Los Angeles's status as a 'city of stars' in the entertainment industry.
The Galaxy have their own official craft beer, the 'Galaxy Blonde,' brewed by a local LA brewery.
The record for the most goals in a single season for the Galaxy is held by Carlos Ruiz, with 24 goals in 2002.
The Galaxy's home stadium, Dignity Health Sports Park, has a capacity of 27,000 for soccer matches.
The Galaxy were the first team in MLS history to win five MLS Cups.
The team's official colors are navy blue, gold, and white.
The Galaxy's highest-scoring game was a 7-4 victory over the Colorado Rapids in 1998.
The team's rivalry with LAFC is known as 'El Tráfico,' a playful nod to Los Angeles's notorious traffic congestion.
The Galaxy's original jerseys in 1996 featured a unique teal and black color scheme with a swirling logo.
The LA Galaxy have their own charitable foundation, the LA Galaxy Foundation, which focuses on youth soccer and community initiatives.
The team's first-ever draft pick was defender Robin Fraser.
The Galaxy have a 'Ring of Honor' at their stadium to commemorate legendary players like Cobi Jones and Mauricio Cienfuegos.
The team's all-time leader in appearances is Cobi Jones, with over 300 games played for the club.
The Galaxy have played friendly matches against international giants like Real Madrid, Manchester United, and Barcelona.
The team's first Designated Player was Landon Donovan, not David Beckham.
The Galaxy's mascot Cozmo wears the number 96 on his jersey, representing the team's inaugural season in 1996.
The Galaxy's home stadium has hosted the MLS Cup final a record six times.
The team's original home stadium was the Rose Bowl in Pasadena.
The Galaxy's team motto is 'This is LA.'
The 'high five' was allegedly invented by Dodgers outfielder Dusty Baker in 1977 after hitting his 30th home run.
The first-ever televised baseball game was between the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Cincinnati Reds in 1939.
Dodger Stadium has its own dedicated ZIP code: 90090.
The Dodgers and the New York Yankees have met in the World Series 11 times, more than any other pair of teams.
The Dodgers' iconic script logo was first introduced in 1938.
The Dodgers were the first MLB team to have a female general manager, Kim Ng (though she was an assistant GM at the time).
The color of Dodger Stadium's seats was chosen to mimic the colors of the Southern California sky at different times of day, from yellow to orange to blue.
The Dodgers' spring training facility, Camelback Ranch, is shared with the Chicago White Sox.
The legendary 'Fernandomania' of the 1980s saw pitcher Fernando Valenzuela become a cultural icon and the first player to win Rookie of the Year and the Cy Young Award in the same season.
The Dodgers were the first MLB team to open an office in Asia, establishing a presence in Tokyo in 1998.
The team's official song is 'It's Time for Dodger Baseball,' written by organist Nancy Bea Hefley.
The Dodgers' organist, Dieter Ruehle, also plays for the Los Angeles Lakers and Kings.
The Dodgers have retired the number 42 for Jackie Robinson league-wide, but they also have their own retired numbers, including Sandy Koufax's 32 and Roy Campanella's 39.
The Dodgers have a 'Legends of Dodger Baseball' series to honor players who are not in the Hall of Fame but were significant to the franchise, like Steve Garvey and Don Newcombe.
The team's mascot, the 'Dodger,' is a costumed character that was introduced in the 1980s but is rarely seen.
The Dodgers were the first team to wear batting helmets in a game in 1941.
The team's famous 'Dodger Dog' is a 10-inch pork hot dog, distinct from the all-beef hot dogs sold at most other ballparks.
Dodger Stadium is built into a hillside, so fans can park on the same level as their seats, minimizing the need for ramps and stairs.
The Dodgers' original name in Brooklyn was the 'Brooklyn Grays.' They were also called the 'Bridegrooms,' 'Superbas,' and 'Robins' before officially becoming the Dodgers.
The Dodgers were the first team to win a World Series on the West Coast, in 1959.
The team's official charity, the Los Angeles Dodgers Foundation, focuses on education, health care, and social justice.
The Dodgers have had four consecutive Rookies of the Year from 1993 to 1996: Mike Piazza, Raúl Mondesí, Hideo Nomo, and Todd Hollandsworth.
The Dodgers' 'Bleacher Creatures' fan section in right field is known for its passionate and sometimes rowdy support.
The Dodgers' 1988 World Series victory is considered one of the biggest upsets in baseball history, as they defeated the heavily favored Oakland Athletics.
The Dodgers' longtime manager, Tommy Lasorda, managed the team for 20 seasons and also won a gold medal as the manager of the U.S. Olympic baseball team in 2000.
Dodger Stadium has appeared in numerous films, including 'The Fast and the Furious' and 'Naked Gun.'
The Dodgers' rivalry with the San Francisco Giants is one of the oldest and most intense in all of sports, dating back to when both teams were in New York.
The Dodgers' broadcaster, Vin Scully, called games for the team for an incredible 67 seasons, from 1950 in Brooklyn to 2016 in Los Angeles.
The team's 'Think Blue' slogan originated in the 1970s.
The Dodgers' 1965 starting rotation featured two Hall of Fame pitchers, Sandy Koufax and Don Drysdale.
The iconic term 'slam dunk' was coined by legendary Lakers announcer Chick Hearn.
Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored his record 38,387 career points with only one three-point shot made in his entire career.
The Lakers' 33-game winning streak during the 1971-72 season is the longest winning streak in the history of major American professional sports.
The first-ever NBA game was played by the Minneapolis Lakers' predecessor, the Detroit Gems, who had a dismal 4-40 record.
The 'Forum Blue' color of the Lakers' jerseys was chosen by owner Jack Kent Cooke to evoke a sense of royalty, not the LA sky.
The Lakers have had the first overall pick in the NBA draft only three times in their history.
The Lakers' logo was designed in 1960 by a local LA artist named Frank O'Collins, who was paid only $500 for his work on the logo and the team's first program.
The Lakers' team plane was a customized Boeing 757 nicknamed 'Laker Air,' one of the first and most luxurious private planes in pro sports.

The Lakers' 'Showtime' era of the 1980s was known for its fast-breaking, entertaining style of play, which was a stark contrast to the slower, more methodical style of their rivals, the Boston Celtics.
The Lakers have retired the jerseys of 11 players, including legends like Magic Johnson, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, and Kobe Bryant.
The Lakers have had three different home arenas in Los Angeles: the Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena, The Forum, and the Crypto.com Arena (formerly Staples Center).
The Lakers have had three separate 'three-peats' (winning three consecutive championships) in their history: 1952-54, 2000-02, and have aimed for it several other times.
The Lakers' all-time leading scorer is Kobe Bryant, with 33,643 points.
The Lakers have had 26 different head coaches in their history.
The Lakers have had a player win the NBA MVP award eight times.
The Lakers have had a player win the NBA Finals MVP award 13 times.
The Lakers' rivalry with the Boston Celtics is the most storied in the NBA, with the two teams meeting in the NBA Finals a record 12 times.
The Lakers' 'Hollywood' nights jerseys are a special edition uniform that pays homage to the entertainment industry in Los Angeles.
The Lakers have had a player on the All-NBA First Team 62 times, the most in league history.
The Lakers' G League affiliate is the South Bay Lakers, who play their home games in El Segundo.
The Lakers have had a player win the NBA Sixth Man of the Year award three times.
The Lakers have had a player win the NBA Defensive Player of the Year award once (Michael Cooper in 1987).
The Lakers' highest-scoring game was a 162-158 victory over the Golden State Warriors in 1990.
The Lakers have had the best record in the NBA 16 times in their history.
The Lakers have had a player on the NBA All-Rookie First Team 24 times.
The Lakers have had a player on the NBA All-Defensive First Team 24 times.
The Lakers have had a player lead the league in scoring 12 times.
The Lakers have had a player lead the league in rebounds 13 times.
The Lakers have had a player lead the league in assists 9 times.
The Lakers have had a player lead the league in steals 6 times.
